chapter.title: Introduction to Linux Containers
chapter.para: Linux containers are a lightweight virtualization method to run multiple virtual units (containers) simultaneously on a single host. This is similar to the environment. Containers are isolated with kernel Control Groups () and kernel Namespaces.

Containers provide virtualization at the operating system level where the kernel controls the isolated containers. This is unlike full virtualization solutions like &xen; or &kvm; where the processor simulates a complete hardware environment and controls virtual machines.

Conceptually, containers can be seen as an improved technique. The difference is that a chroot environment separates only the file system, whereas containers go further and provide resource management and control via .

listitem.para: Isolating applications and operating systems through containers.
Providing nearly native performance as container manages allocation of resources in real-time.
Controlling network interfaces and applying resources inside containers through .
All containers run inside the host system's kernel and not with a different kernel.
